entry.title: My top 5 Ruby on Rails resources
entry.content:
I first started coding in Ruby in 2011 and I've felt in love with it ever since- mainly because of the community and support behind it. Listed below are the top 5 resources I used the most while I was learning this beautiful programming language.

  1. Ruby on Rails Tutorial by Michael Hartl
    This is THE book to pick up if you are just starting out with Ruby on Rails. It covers all the basics- What is MVC, setting up models, views and controllers, authentication systems, setting up databases, scaffolding and etc. I like how it starts you off with a test-driven development mindset as well.

  2. Rubymonk
    What is the use of learning a framework like Rails if you dont have the right foundation which is the Ruby language? Rubymonk is here for that. They offer interactive Ruby tutorials in your browser. If you are a hands-on learner who likes to jump right into the code and have a crack at it- Rubymonk is for you.

  3. Railscasts
    This is by far my favourite and most-used resource. Ryan Bates (the man behind the website) records himself going through every one of the tutorials available on the site. He covers a broad range of topics for all levels of development skills. Here are some good ones: Devise, Image Uploading, Simple Form, Site-wide Announcements, and Sending Emails

  4. StackOverflow
    Answers to all your Ruby questions lurk on StackOverflow. If you dont find the right answers, then you are not asking the right questions. (Try pasting in the error message- sometimes it works)

  5. Google
    Last but not least, Google should be your first point of question if you get stuck on something. Most often it will show you the related StackOverflow articles, but sometimes it may lead you to a beautifully written tutorial for the subject, or a meticulously crafted blogpost (like this!).

entry.title: My list of useful Ruby Gems
entry.content:
Useful list of Ruby gems that I frequently use in web development projects.

Front End Frameworks

  • Zurb Foundation - Uses SASS
  • Twitter Bootstrap - Uses LESS

Markup/Styling

  • HAML - Prettify your HTML. Looks much cleaner than erb.
  • SASS - Avoid spaghetti CSS. Uses SASS today.
  • Font-Awesome - Icon-fonts

Forms

  • Simple Form - Form generator: labels, error states, dropdowns, checkboxes, etc

Error Reporting

  • Better Errors - Meaningful error screens
  • Rails Panel - Show Rails app requests in Chrome Dev Tool

Authentication

  • Devise - THE authentication system for Rails

Authorization

  • Omniauth - Login with Facebook, Twitter, g+ etc.
  • CanCan - Role-based Authorization (RBA) system that restricts what resources a given user is allowed to access

File/Image Upload

  • CarrierWave - Upload images/files from Rails application

Asset Pipeline

  • Fog - Upload images to cloud
  • Asset Sync - Sync and serve assets from S3, Cloudfront etc.

Pagination

  • Kaminari - Easily create pagination when entries from db queries get too long.

Background Tasks

  • Delayed Job - Execute longer tasks like emailing a long list of entries in the background.

Admin Panels

  • Active Admin - Instantly create an admin panel for your rails app.
  • Rails Admin - Another great admin panel for managing your data

Content Management System

  • RefineryCMS - Popular Rails based CMS

entry.title: Jekyll is up and running
entry.content:
Finally got Jekyll up and running tonight. What is Jekyll you ask? Well, according to its Github page, Jekyll is a simple, blog aware, static site generator. Thats what it does! It takes all the blogposts you write in markdown and generates a static site from them. You can drop the generated files into any web server and you will be able to serve those pages to your reader.

Jekyll is hacker-style blogging. Write your posts in a text editor in markdown, run rake generate, commit your files, and push it to your site's servers. That's how you publish a Jekyll-powered blogpost. The posts are served in .html too, which makes the page load extremely fast!
